title: Frictionless Transferring of Wallet Ownership

profile.name: Enter
profile.about: Keeps people out of collections while getting businesses paid.

vulnerability_information:
In the Robocoin application, users can create their own personal or operator wallets and then share it with other Robocoin users. 

It was observed that this sharing of wallets with other users is frictionless. In other words, the users with whom the wallet is shared with (Let's say B and C) are not asked to confirm this transfer or ownership at all. They are not notified either. 

What this means is that a malicious Robocoin user (Let's say A) would create a wallet and then share it with both B and C (assuming A was able to find some random phone numbers associated with some Robocoin users - this is possible since there was no rate limiting observed for this feature. See attached screenshots where 14 invalid requests were sent with an invalid phone number and the 15th request was a valid number. Notice the difference in the response) as Signers. A then goes ahead and makes B the wallet owner. 

Since B is the wallet owner now, this changes A's permissions and now A becomes a Signer along with the other signer C (who A assigned as a Signer originally). There are no email notifications sent to notify B and C who shared the wallet with them, who transferred ownership from A to B. No notifications of any kinds.

C then logs on and notices that a new wallet is being shared with him. C looks at the user summary of the wallet and notices that B is the owner and both A and C are signers. C becomes suspicious that B is the malicious user and has shared the wallet with both A and C. 

In a nutshell, A spoofed B as the wallet owner. The fact that there are no notifications being sent of any kind and that there is no rate limiting observed for the sharing feature only makes this issue more feasible and prone to an attack.

There are some other ramifications as well due to this behavior such as:

A can share this wallet with any number of Robocoin users. This would allow different Robocoin users to view each other's phone numbers. In a way, this is basically revealing phone numbers of various Robocoin users to each other which is totally unnecessary. Revealing a phone number is worse than revealing a name IMHO. 

This would also allow a large number of wallets being shown in Robocoin user dashboards to which they have no connection whatsoever. 

Cheers!
/ab
vulnerability_information_html:
In the Robocoin application, users can create their own personal or operator wallets and then share it with other Robocoin users.

It was observed that this sharing of wallets with other users is frictionless. In other words, the users with whom the wallet is shared with (Let's say B and C) are not asked to confirm this transfer or ownership at all. They are not notified either.

What this means is that a malicious Robocoin user (Let's say A) would create a wallet and then share it with both B and C (assuming A was able to find some random phone numbers associated with some Robocoin users - this is possible since there was no rate limiting observed for this feature. See attached screenshots where 14 invalid requests were sent with an invalid phone number and the 15th request was a valid number. Notice the difference in the response) as Signers. A then goes ahead and makes B the wallet owner.

Since B is the wallet owner now, this changes A's permissions and now A becomes a Signer along with the other signer C (who A assigned as a Signer originally). There are no email notifications sent to notify B and C who shared the wallet with them, who transferred ownership from A to B. No notifications of any kinds.

C then logs on and notices that a new wallet is being shared with him. C looks at the user summary of the wallet and notices that B is the owner and both A and C are signers. C becomes suspicious that B is the malicious user and has shared the wallet with both A and C.

In a nutshell, A spoofed B as the wallet owner. The fact that there are no notifications being sent of any kind and that there is no rate limiting observed for the sharing feature only makes this issue more feasible and prone to an attack.

There are some other ramifications as well due to this behavior such as:

A can share this wallet with any number of Robocoin users. This would allow different Robocoin users to view each other's phone numbers. In a way, this is basically revealing phone numbers of various Robocoin users to each other which is totally unnecessary. Revealing a phone number is worse than revealing a name IMHO.

This would also allow a large number of wallets being shown in Robocoin user dashboards to which they have no connection whatsoever.

Cheers!
/ab

activities.message:
See the attached screenshot. I wanted to stress on the Information Disclosure part. As you can see, the name along with their phone numbers is visible to everybody. An attacker can potentially automate this and farm for all Robocoin user names and their phone numbers which can then be used for other sophisticated attacks. 

If I were a Robocoin user, I wouldn't want anybody to know my number and name who I haven't authorized or don't know. Revealing / Enumerating phone numbers and usernames exclusively is one thing but enumerating them both together gives a better idea of the real identity of the user.

activities.message:
Hey there, 

We believe to have resolved this issue by addressing it as follows:

1) Transferring ownership of an account to a new user now requires another factor of authentication.
2) All transfers, shares, and removals will send emails to both parties involved.
3) User phone numbers are no longer listed in the shared list.

You can confirm?
activities.markdown_message:
Hey there,

We believe to have resolved this issue by addressing it as follows:

1) Transferring ownership of an account to a new user now requires another factor of authentication.
2) All transfers, shares, and removals will send emails to both parties involved.
3) User phone numbers are no longer listed in the shared list.

You can confirm?

activities.message:
Hey,

All the above 3 fixes look good. However, I did notice that the rate limiting for adding a phone number has still not been implemented. I was able to send 16 invalid phone numbers and then the 17th one was a valid number registered on the Robocoin application. As a result, I was able to add that person to my wallet. All I required was a request where I went through a list of phone numbers in the `phone` parameter as shown below:

```
POST /dashboard/account/<redacted>/sharing/create HTTP/1.1
Host: wallet.robocoin.com
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://wallet.robocoin.com/dashboard
Content-Length: 112
Cookie: SESSION=<redacted>
Connection: keep-alive
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache

phone=%2B1+<phone_number>&countryCode=US&bankAccountPermissionType=SIGNER&_csrf=<redacted>
```

So, to summarize, even with all the above fixes, I can still add any random Robocoin user to my wallet and leverage the Robocoin platform to send them emails (makes this a mass spamming attack). When a phone number that is registered on the application gets a hit (like the 17th one in my case), the person associated with that number gets added to my wallet. The name of that person then appears in the wallet shared list. So, this itself is enumeration where any malicious attacker can potentially go through a bunch of phone numbers and try to share his wallet with them. When a number works and the name appears, the attacker will know the victim's number and name, essentially reproducing the information disclosure issue again. The only difference here is that `only` the attacker is able to enumerate users and not other users with whom the wallet is shared.

I would recommend implementing rate limitation in the above request and that should take care of all the issues described in this report. 

Let me know if you have any other questions or concerns. 

Cheers!
/ab

activities.message: Thanks ab.  We resolved your final concern by rate limiting sharing accounts to 10 requests an hour.

activities.message:
Thank you for helping us resolve this issue.  In this case, our security was adjusted for better defense in depth, but no direct exploitation is possible.  As a result, we are rewarding $50 for identifying it.
Thanks again!
